comments.commentBody:
Republicans have no interest in genuinely fixing Social Security. They want to destroy it and replace it with some form of privatized retirement. When President Obama makes a suggestion that sounds like the system might be shored up, of course they oppose it, because preservation is not their goal.

Additionally they see Social Security as a source of borrowing revenues for the government, which they also want to destroy. So their claims of wanting to save it is a flat lie. The sooner Americans wake up to this brute fact, they might finally vote these reprobates out of our lives. This will be a blessing for both old and young.

Paul,

R.E.B. pointed out that your Keynesian prescription for growth failed in the 70's so why would it work now? Your rebuttal in essence was that price level inflation in the 70's wasn't a monetary, but a commodity supply-side problem, therefore it doesn't count as a valid Keynesian intervention (what episode in history will ever satisfy Keynesians is besides the point).

To that I responded with data you brushed over and proceeded to another time period.......let's stick with the 70's for now, ok?

a) The US, at no time during the oil embargo had a real oil shortage.
b) Monetary expansion preceded CPI inflation. The oil embargo came after CPI inflation was well on its way.
http://www.nber.org/chapters/c11065.pdf

Do you copy?

Now as to 2008-2013.

a) CPI method changed in 1999
b) Prices are inflating despite the greatest amount of unemployment in 80 years. Relative to such decimated demand, the price level is still inflating and real wages are eroding accordingly. Not fast enough for you?
c) The Fed engineered what you and Paul Krugman think is a liquidity trap. Liquidity if being channeled into asset prices, not consumer prices, in order to save the big banks. There is your inflation. In the 70's the inflating asset was a commodity. Today, it's stocks and bonds. Seigniorage always first goes into assets then consumer prices.

The Keynesian prescription failed in the 70's and it has failed today. Get over it. Hayek was right!

You bring up an important point, in the ad world which should be cutting edge and ahead of the time... there are still a large number of people and companies resistant to change... resistant to turning heads. Many companies say they want to be noticed but it takes a lot these days to be noticed. When approaching a board with a "new and interesting" idea, it may be best to have a version of the finished product ready and available... video can translate a message that would otherwise be lost, by the same token the ideas/storyline of a video verbally represented in a meeting may leave the buyers detached, lost... in the gap.

Furthermore, I looked at your site and love the work you have done.. The Mackie is great. At ForwardMotionCreative we work to elevate entertainment in advertising. Dollar Shave club is a great example, of course we inform the consumer why not entertain.
Yep, he's like a has-been rock star at an oldies show getting all excited because he got cheers for saying the name of their town.

"I will never understand why age discrimination laws protect old age but not youth."--Mark R
Dear Mark:
Yes, you will.

Exactly who does Mr. Oxford think is his audience for this piece -- "social media powerhouse LinkedIn" is obvious and pandering while "OMG frown" just sounds desperate to be "with it". Let's not even mention the anachronistic Dylanesque phrase "the times, they are a-changing" . The turns of phrase ping pong across cliches.

It strikes me that this column would play better on that sardonic PR vehicle "Fast Company" where stating the age of each profiled subject was passed off as useful information when in fact it was just a signifer of hip, happening, nowness.

Here's to never getting old, Mr. Oxford.
Only seven previous comments on this post? Hard to believe. It's certainly the ugliest thing I've ever read in the Times.

I tend to be color, gender, and age "blind", but I do segregate people into two groups: those that get "it", and those that don't. With this second article you have more securely established yourself among the group that does "not get it".

Your basic premise is much like that employed by car dealerships when things are slow, i.e. add a bunch of commission only sales people to increase the in-house competition among the sales force at little cost to the dealership. Suddenly, all your salesmen are working 16 hour days, and sales may increase slightly because everyone smells blood and goes into survival mode. Of course, your short term strategy also runs off the professional sales people on your team, leaving you with a large, incompetent, and unprofessional staff that you now get to manage as your long term prospects dim due to your reduced institutionalized knowledge.

Applies to things other than car dealerships too.

No offense to the 20 somethings out there, but I'd rather have someone working for me 8 hours a day that gets the job done, than someone working 18 hours a day that is a frenzy of unfocused activity due to lack of experience.

Indeed, let's step back and take deep breaths. What the President has proposed is not yet a reality, and while it may become one, there are ways to mitigate the projected lowering of SS payments. One that must be addressed is the costs of health care. Medicare For All, and a gutting of the medical-industrial-pharmaceutical complex with their inflated charges would be a good place to start.

Let's step back. Take several slow, deep breaths, focus on stress release. Clear our minds, ignore the sound bites, and decide who we are going to unelect in 2014. That's the best and lasting fix to resolving the issues surrounding paid-in benefits and women's rights.

Thanks bunches for coming back so we can see how vast your cluelessness is, not that it's surprising in a salesman (sales isn't particularly a reality-based task). To start with you're obviously clueless about the importance of audience. On Twitter your audience is folks who choose to follow you, mostly folks who like and think like you. Here you're confronted with a more diverse audience. As a result the comment section here is probably a better reflection of reality. Then there's your economic cluelessness. As it happens those who come into the job market in a recession find their lifetime earnings are invariably reduced. Their wages also tend to be depressed and don't fully recover for decades.

But, hey, what more should we expect from someone who seems define an entrepreneur as someone who lives like a greyhound at the race track, running as hard as they can after the next hot fad or cool sounding idea, or perhaps all you really run after is the money.

Yes, mental health is important. But it does not appear that murders by firearms went untreated or would have been placed on a list by a judge. So regardless, the issue is the availability of and the negligent way that guns are treated within a household and by sellers.

This omits the most important change: lift the stigma on mental illness. That may be the biggest deterrent to people seeking help - not wanting to get tagged as 'crazy' by friends, neighbours, and employers. Your community centres will sit empty, because no one will want to associate with anyone seen going into or out of them.

Some years ago the original Law & Order did an episode, 'Pro Se,' in which a schizophrenic lawyer defends himself against a charge of murder. His sister testifies to his struggle with his illness: he hated his meds because they muddled and dulled his mind, but took them in order to return to society, only to find no one would hire a man with a history of mental illness. He deliberately goes off his meds at trial, giving up his defence.

Attitudes can change. When I was a child, adults never admitted anyone had cancer. It was a shameful secret, referred to in hushed tones as 'a lingering illness', seen as a sign of God's disfavour or moral turpitude'. Someday we will recognize mental illness as a brain disorder. But until we can answer the plaintive cry of Sylvia Frumkin in the great memoir of that title - 'Is there no place on earth for me? - with 'yes, we will make one, we will not cast you out,' the mentally ill will hide in fear and shame, and their families will help hide them. Some of them will get worse, some will go over an edge.

Gun violence and treatment for mental illness have very little to do with one another.

Nice that there will hopefully be more help out there for the mentally ill, but too bad it has to be because of gun violence instead of compassion for those needing treatment.

Which of these recent mass murderers was seeking care, but turned away due to a lack of resources? Zero. I'm all for increased community mental health resources, but that's not going to help reduce these type of tragedies. The primary barrier to protecting the public is the much-too-high legal threshold for involuntary hospitalization. The way most current laws are written, a person needs to act violently FIRST before we can admit/detain them. Anyone see the flaw here?

(And yes, lowering the threshold will mean more people who will never become violent will be involuntarily hospitalized. I'm okay with that. There's no perfect solution, so I'm okay with erring on the side of some civli liberty infringement. I prefer that to putting school kids in body bags.)

I don;t think infusion of public funds into the mental health system is likely to have a quick or direct impact on mass , gun involved violence, although I am glad to see this new interest in invigorating the long neglected public mental health agencies. I think this long neglect of mental health has been part of the national drift since the Reagan era of neglect of the public welfare. I suspect the outbreaks of mass violence have something to do with this neglect over time. Still it is interesting that the politicians can;t seem to come together to do the immediate rational thing of removing dangerous weaponry from society: one could argue the easy availability of such weaponry is itself crazy. so, there is no agreement to fix a crazy system, but there is agreement to allot more money to identify and treat individual mental health cases.

It is about time that mental illness receives its recognition as a serious disease and stands on its own platform as such,but with one tiniest of caveats. Sad as it is,it is in the forefront now only as a by-prodict of the most recent horrific massacre of 20 angels and their six guardians, otherwise it would remain in the back burner.The miniscule caveat is that mental disease not be overdiagnosed, and such diagnosis be only rendered by men and women with trained expertise in the field; and this indeed is a very complex field. For  once an individual, specially a young person is diagnosed with  mental defect, that person is labeled for life and this may well change the course of his or her entire future.There is also the issue  that overdiagnosis leads to overtreatment; as a topical example would be aome children loosely labeled to have ADHD and arguably may not fall in that category.It behooves the experts in this field of mental illness, that above all do no harm.
well said

No one has a magic cure for troubled minds. Really, we don't.

Psychology is a "soft" science, and its success is highly dependent on the connection between the patient and the counselor. Psychiatry is a "hard" science only when dealing with some Axis I disorders (e.g. depression, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder).

So if a counselor/doctor sees someone with a 'weird look in their eye" and some time later they commit a crime, is the provider culpable for not reporting or curing them? How do you arrest someone or isolate someone from society if they have not actually committed a crime? You can't. (Thank God, you can't.)

Would counseling or medications have averted the tragedies in CO, AZ or CT? In the case of each of these particular shooters, I doubt it. In fact, I think all 3 of these men had at least some mental health services prior to their crimes. So do we blame their doctors/counselors/parents/friends/neighbors for not 'fixing' them? That's the easy way out. Just blame someone who might have known ahead of time that something could happen. Now we have someone to blame, but we still don't have a cure for their illnesses, and we still didn't avert the crimes.

That said, I'm all for more mental health services. Many patients can and do benefit from them. I'm just not convinced that these patients are our potential shooters.

To stop the shootings, get rid of the guns.

We are in our infancy in finding out why brains develop the way they do - impacted by genetic, environmental, chemical factors - and I do not doubt the profit motive of Big Pharm is unhelpful. But I would not describe the situation is such catastrophic terms as you do.

I also know of many situations where the only thing that was keeping a young person from harming others were the (very poor) medications we have in existence.

Keep in mind President Obama also wanted to seed fund additional brain research. We have a long way to go. That said, we ALSO know how to CREATE monstrous behaviors. Put any child in a mega-dysfunctional environment filled with anxiety, fear, violence - and you can impact their brain functioning as well as their behaviors. But that also does not mean all violence is caused by bad parenting or societal woes. Like seeking a cure for cancer, we are looking a scores of factors and one treatment does NOT fit all.
I wish I could recommend Doc B's response a hundred times.

"President Obama has also joined the effort. His budget includes $130 million for programs that would help detect mental illness in young children, train educators to spot those signs and refer the students to treatment."
This is horrific. I bet Big Pharma is salivating profusely at the prospect of more fresh young meat to "treat" with their medically dangerous and largely psychiatrically ineffective potions.
Let us all remember the proliferation, since the 1990s to present, of ADHD diagnoses; or Bipolar diagnoses in kids - as young as 2-3 years old, prompted by the propaganda spread by the so-called Key Opinion Leaders of American Psychiatry (a k a academics in psychiatry departments at various medical schools, including Harvard and other Ivy Leagues, who were on BigPharma's payroll, directly or indirectly)...
Also, we must remain cognizant that a large number of ADHD diagnoses are prompted by complaints from overworked, overwhelmed and perversely incentivized teachers who, together with the school systems, pressure ignorant, overworked, overwhelmed and (sometimes) perversely incentivized parents into having their crazed, but not crazy, kids (whose brains and personality have not yet matured/solidified) undergo "treatment" with powerful psychotropic agents.
Once again, Psychiatry is asked to act as the arm of the state to id and "treat" the inconvenient victims of social, cultural and moral bankruptcy of a nation, and Psychiatry, as always, will docilely comply. Sick.

Most folks live with undiagnosed mental illness. Just the slightest stressor sets off many of the things that you have listed.
The fact is, more people die by suicide than by homicide in this country.

Amen! This would increase everyone's safety -- especially peace officers who are often put at risk in situations where they must confront or talk down strangers who may be armed or have access to arms.

Anyone who threatens to kill somebody should be considered mentally ill. Stalkers of women, angry ex-husbands, disgruntled employees and students, politically-motivated conspiracy fanatics, one and all. If they tell somebody they want to kill somebody, that should be grounds for arrest and involuntary mental evaluation. "I was just joking" should not be a defense. As part of the evaluation, police should be issued search warrants and if guns are found in the person's home, they should be confiscated. "Mental health" covers a lot of territory. What we need to be focusing on is those with violent potential and the means (guns) to carry it out.

How sadly odd that even a sliver of compassion for those suffering illness we categorize as "mental" comes because those who love guns more than life seek to squirm out from under any form of control or restriction over their obsession with weapons. Perhaps if enough "poor" children simply started shooting as many "rich" people as they could obtain guns and ammo we'd discover a new compassion for children living in poverty? Only after we'd filled our prisons with them, I'd guess. After all, that's where we house a significant portion of our mentally ill citizens. Welcome to the land of compassionate conservatism.

As a former teacher, I could and did spot the students who would be something other than discipline prolems. One was committed to a locked facility, another was arrested and tried, convicted, and sentenced for felonious property damage, and a third with asperger's syndrome was withdrawsn from school. The cases who might do harm to humans are not so difficult to spot. Certainly, there are those few who appear normal yet are capable of unthinkable problems. Yes, I was very busy also, but I took the time to identify these three.

Furthermore, as seen, teachers are the the true first responders. Besides being psychiatric experts, medical emergency experts, test-teaching experts, answerers of parental e-mails, attendees of required seminars on better teaching delivered by pricey consultants who are experts in teaching (?), now they must become sharp-shooting in panic situation experts with SWAT team skills, and if that fails, to attempt to shield their students with their own bodies from the bullets spitting out of massacre-style guns. Who is it that is mentally ill?

It would be more efficient to require ten people known to the prospective gun purchaser to vouch for his/her mental balance and ability to control the access to guns that may be purchased.

Also, to require that anyone owning or purchasing a massacre-style gun pass the exact same training and the exact same physical, skill, and psychological tests required for actual FBI or other government SWAT team members.

In Aurora, it could have been prevented or delayed if the theater management had someone check periodically to assure that the exit doors are locked so that no one can get in from the outside. The Newtown shooters mother should have kept her arsenal in a locked safe. At Virginia Tech, the psychiatrist had notified University police that the person who did the shooting had problems that made him a threat to others. At Columbine, the shooters' parents should have been and may have been aware that those two had a propensity for harm to others. In Arizona, the shooter was able to go through a crowd with an arsenal of weapons, nobody yelled for help or tried to stop him. All of these could have been prevented if people had been alert and acted.

Sonny,  You are correct in your analysis. It is better to begin a course correct now that to pretend there is nothing that can be done about it.  There are always going to be exceptions to any law like Lanza, but violence can be prevented in the day to day assaults that are not exceptions by applying better regulation and better mental health resources.

I agree with what you say.  The killings are a symptom of a exploitive society that treats the weak and vulnerable with contempt.  Personally, I think guns play only a small part and that background checks and magazine restrictions are meaningless (I understand you may not agree).  If someone is so sick that he wants to murder dozens of little children, he doesn't need a gun to do it - they are defenseless - and we cannot keep our children locked up for safety.  I am uncertain whether any mental health initiative would have helped Seung-Hui Cho, Jared Loughner, John Holmes, Adam Lanza because, although they were all clinically mentally ill, they would not have accepted voluntary committent and none of them were eligible to be committed involuntarily.  If they had been unable to get guns, they would have set fires  (e.g., Happyland Social Club) or done something equally despicable.  The same is true for the gun suicide statistics (see Hungary and Japan, no guns, highest suicide rates). All this does nothing to change the underlying problems.

Bravo!!! My sentiments exactly. Ronald Reagan began the $$ cuts on the federal level. And, they keep getting cut each year...virtually non-existent. State participation is a joke, at least in Louisiana. There are hardly any beds to treat the mentally ill. Closing of mental hospitals and overloaded/overworked community mental health centers. I could just scream!!!
I thank you for your comments.

Paulie, Thanks for the hermeneutics. Agreement that there is more than just the rampage problem is the beginning of the coming together that is needed to heal the self imposed rifts on the fabric of our society.

Reasonable regulation of the manufacture, importation, sale and distribution of firearms means less deaths. State that currently require background checks have 38% fewer spousal deaths due to firearms than the those states that don't have them.

Most gun violence is not the Adam Lanza style, except in the beginning of his rampage where he took the life of his closest association and in the final moment of the same spree where he took his own life.

The mental illness component of the senseless gun violence epidemic takes lives of those closest and suicide in a relentless onslaught day and night across the nation. That is why the regulation of firearms is the sadly forgotten part of the second amendment.

The root of the mental illness/homelessness blight on our society started in the 1980s with cuts in funding for the neediest in our country as part of the divisive policies espoused by supposed conservatives to win political points.

A major course correction is needed not just in policies of the weapons regulations and mental health assistance availability, but in the attitudes that allow people to look down on others as unworthy of help.
